Award.AwardTitle: Advanced quantum chemical methods for strong correlation and beyond
Award.AbstractNarration:
Garnet Chan of Princeton University is supported by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry division to develop new quantum chemical methods for "hard" problems in quantum chemistry. The main directions of the research are (1) extending the density matrix renormalization group and related methodologies to tackle the electronic structure of multi-centre transition metal sites as found in bioinorganic systems, (2) developing new approaches to strong correlation based on higher dimensional tensor networks, and (3) exploring the use of correlated wavefunction methodologies for problems of quantum spin dynamics in electron spin and nuclear magnetic resonance.

Beyond the dissemination of science, algorithms, and code associated with this research, the broader impacts of this proposal are focused on the development of educational modules for quantum mechanics through the NETLOGO environment, and the establishment of an online "Ask a Scientist" resource for chemistry and other sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has helped to fund new ways to simulate the behaviour of complex molecules on a computer. In particular, simulation methods have been developed that can model the properties of enzymes that are important to many of life's processes, including the way in which nitrogen enters the foodchain to make amino acids, and photosynthesis. The complicated active centers of these enzymes consist of multiple transition metal ions, whose electrons exhibit correlated motion. Describing this electronic motion properly has long been a major challenge in constructing faithful computer simulations of these systems.

Over the period of the grant, several new techniques were developed to model correlated electron motion in transition metals. One of these, the density matrix renormalization group, grew to sufficient maturity where it could be used to carry out the first computer simulations of the simultaneous correlated motion of all electrons in the enzyme active sites associated with photosynthesis and nitrogen fixation. In the latter period of the grant, many additional capabilities were added to this simulation technique, for example to allow for the atomic positions to move, and to simulate spectroscopy experiments. In addition, successors to the density matrix renormalization group, so called tensor network methods, were also explored, and it is expected that these methods will be able to overtake the capabilities developed in this grant sometime in the future. Overall, the main intellectual impact of this grant has been to make simulations of complicated electronic motion in biological systems a real possibility.

More broadly, this grant has also helped to fund the development of publicly available simulation software that can be used by a broader community of chemists, material scientists and physicists. The grant has also helped to train many scientists at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral level that are helping to build the US scientific workforce. The work in this grant has been disseminated very broadly at lectures delivered to the general public at Caltech and through the web.
